title-group.article-title: Deriving causal Bayesian networks from human reliability analysis data: A methodology and example model

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Risk and Reliability, University of Maryland, USA

author-notes.corresp: Katrina M Groth, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0748, USA Email: kgroth@sandia.gov

abstract.p: Within the probabilistic risk assessment community, there is a widely acknowledged need to improve the scientific basis of human reliability analysis (HRA). This has resulted in a number of independent research efforts to gather empirical data to validate HRA methods and a number of independent research efforts to improve theoretical models of human performance used in HRA. This paper introduces a methodology for carefully combining multiple sources of empirical data with validated theoretical models to enhance both qualitative and quantitative HRA applications. The methodology uses a comprehensive set of performance influencing factors to combine data from different sources. Further, the paper describes how to use data to gather insights into the relationships among performance influencing factors and to build a quantitative HRA causal model.

To illustrate how the methodology is applied, we introduce the Bayesian network model that resulted from applying the methodology to two sources of human performance data from nuclear power plant operations. The proposed model is introduced to demonstrate how to develop causal insights from HRA data and how to incorporate these insights into a quantitative HRA model. The methodology in this paper provides a path forward for carefully incorporating emerging sources of human performance data into an improved HRA method. The proposed model is a starting point for the next generation of data-informed, theoretically-validated HRA methods.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Human reliability analysis (HRA) is an aspect of risk assessment concerned with systematically identifying and analyzing the causes and consequences of human decisions and actions. It is used to incorporate human risks into system safety analysis as part of an informed approach to reducing overall risk. HRA is an essential component of probabilistic risk assessment (PRA) for complex systems such as nuclear power plants. HRA is used to understand and assess how humans affect system risks, with the ultimate goal of reducing the likelihood and consequences of human errors.

There are numerous HRA methods1–6 that provide guidance for identification of human errors and for assessment of human error probability (HEP). Of the various HRA methods, some are concerned primarily with systematic identification of observable behaviors, some attempt to quantify the probability of human error based on the situational context, and others attempt to model the human and the human’s interactions with the system.7 Different HRA methods view human error as the cause of an event, the event itself, or as the outcome of an event.3 Many HRA methods use performance influencing factors (PIFs), also called performance shaping factors (PSFs), to represent the causes of human errors and to calculate HEPs. The majority of HRA methods have proposed normative relationships that produce HEPs based on the state of the PIFs. However, these methods have several limitations.

Human actions are complex and human failures are not entirely random; current HRA methods are overly simplistic in the way they predict human error probabilities. The need for improved HRA methods is widely acknowledged in the HRA community. (Oxstrand8 provides the most recent comprehensive discussion of the challenges facing the HRA community.) One of the major limitations of current HRA methods is that few existing models attempt to provide a causal picture of human errors. Mosleh and Chang9 cited this as one of the five major limitations in current HRA methodologies, and they articulated the value of a model-based HRA method.

A causal model would explicitly capture the factors that drive human performance and the interrelationships among these factors. The use of causal models can provide more traceable, reproducible HRA predictions. Causal models have both explanatory and predictive capability; they enable us not only to predict the probability of a human error, but also to explain why human errors happen, and what we can do to prevent them. Causal models have been used to capture cause–effect relationships in other human performance application areas such as simulation modeling (e.g. cognitive environment simulation10), but these applications are largely qualitative.

While the value of causal models for HRA purposes is clear, the history of causal models in HRA is limited. Woods11 acknowledged the need for causal modeling over 20 years ago. The use of causal models for HRA began in the 1990s with the IDA methodology,12 CAHR13 and CREAM.3 The first version of the SPAR-H method4 was introduced in 1999, and the technical basis behind SPAR-H has been further refined. In the 2000s, the IDA model was expanded into the IDAC model.5 Recently, quantitative causal models were introduced to the HRA field via two approaches: influence diagrams quantified via the analytic network process14 and data-informed Bayesian network (BN) models.15,16

Causal modeling can also be used to address an additional problem facing HRA: most current HRA quantitative models were derived from expert judgment and intuition. Due to data limitations, there are no benchmarks that can be used to validate any HRA model. However, BN causal models have the ability to incorporate multiple sources of data into a single predictive HRA model. Taking a data-informed, expert-verified approach to HRA adds a new level of validity to HRA.

This paper presents the methodology to develop a data-informed Bayesian (belief) network of PIFs using multiple sources of HRA data. Recently, there has been major international interest in collecting human performance data for nuclear power plant HRA.17 However, there has been limited discussion of how to implement this data to gain better understanding of PIFs, to better estimate human error probabilities, or to assist accident analysis. A BN allows analysts to combine information from several sources, including observational data and expert information.

The final product of this methodology is a causal model which visibly displays the relationships among the PIFs and encodes PIF states and the strength of the relationships in conditional probability tables. A sample BN is introduced in this paper. The scope of this sample model is restricted to gathering the maximum insights from a very limited data set. This model should be viewed as part of a larger framework that goes beyond relying purely on weak data. The larger framework, presented by Groth,18 combines a data-derived model with theory-driven modeling; this framework combines theories, existing causal models, and intuition into a more comprehensive and better validated model in a rigorous and reproducible manner.

The methodology proposed in this paper can also be used to develop a data-informed causal model for predicting HEPs. The next section describes the basic form of a BN model. The section ‘Data sources’ describes the HRA data sources used to construct the model and the section ‘Data analysis techniques’ describes the data analysis techniques assembled to develop the model. The model development methodology is described in the section ‘Model development procedure’ and the sample PIF BN is presented in the section ‘PIF Model development and insights’.

sec.title: 2 BN overview
sec.p: This section provides a brief overview of BNs for readers who may be unfamiliar with this class of causal models. A BN (or Bayesian belief network) is a specific type of quantitative causal model composed of a directed acyclic graph and a set of probability statements. The completed BN is a knowledge base, and Bayesian updating is used to make inferences using the BN.

The graphical part of a BN consists of nodes (the variables or PIFs) and directed arcs (causal influence between nodes). Most BNs use discrete conditional probability tables to express the strength of the relationships between the variables. Bayesian updating is used to analyze and update the state of knowledge about the nodes in the network as additional data (or observations) become available. Bayesian statistical analysis is often used in PRA applications, including those with limited data;19 it has a long history of use in various industries. These industries fall across the risk spectrum, including ecology,20,21 food safety,22 national security,23 and criminology.24 In a Bayesian statistical framework, the completed BN is the prior model, and Bayesian updating is used to propagate different pieces of information (e.g. observations about the human performance context) through the model.

BNs provide a framework for reasoning about events, based on the set of information that is currently available. This is especially beneficial for HRA, since not all of the variables in an HRA model are readily observable.

sec.title: 2.1 BN structure
sec.p: In a BN, each variable is represented as a single node. The nodes must be defined in such a way that each node is a distinctly defined entity, even if it is causally influenced by other elements. Each node has a finite set of mutually exclusive states. Directed arcs are used to indicate causal relationships between nodes, with the arrowhead indicating the direction of causality.

The first step in development of the causal model is to identify the variables to be included as nodes in the model. The variables in the model must be distinctly defined and must be conceptually meaningful in the system being analyzed. The second step is to identify the relationships (arcs) between the variables. The arcs are used to represent a causal relationship between two variables, with the arrowhead indicating the direction of the influence.

sec.title: 2.2 BN quantification
sec.p: Once all relationships among BN nodes are indicated by arcs, each node is assigned a marginal or conditional probability table. These probability tables contain all known information concerning the state of the system based on both expert opinion and available data. In a BN each node is assigned a probability distribution based on the possible states of its parent nodes.

sec.p: Conditional probabilities can be populated by using expert opinion, data, or a combination of both. The method used to develop the PIF model is presented in the section ‘Model quantification’. The reader is referred to Pearl,25 Cowell et al.,26 Lauritzen and Spiegelhalter,27 and Druzdzel and Van der Gaag28 for additional information about conditional probability in BNs.

sec.title: 2.3 Inference in a BN
sec.p: Once a probability distribution is assigned to each node, the initial BN model is complete. In the Bayesian statistical framework, a fully quantified BN represents the prior knowledge for an analyst. To use the model, the analyst makes observations (sets evidence) about certain nodes and examines the impact on the remaining nodes in the network. In HRA, analyst evidence could be the observation of a particular state of a PIF.

By setting evidence, an analyst is providing the model with new information (e.g. recently collected data, hypothetical scenarios) about the state of the system. This information is automatically propagated through the network to produce updated probabilities for all nodes in the model. These updated probabilities are the result of both prior information in the BN and the new evidence. This process can be repeated every time new evidence becomes available.

Once the prior BN is complete, it can be incorporated into HRA models, both as an element of the qualitative analysis process as well as a way to quantify HEPs. A more explicit integration of the HRA causal model with PRA logic models can be accomplished via the hybrid causal logic (HCL) methodology,29,30 which links the BN nodes to other risk models (e.g. fault trees and event trees). Use of HCL enables PRA practitioners to expand deterministic models, which are appropriate for hardware systems, to include more robust treatment of soft causal factors, such as human error, via BN.

sec.title: 3 Data sources
sec.p: In building the PIF BN model, two sources of data were selected for quantitative analysis: the Human Events Repository Analysis (HERA) database31 and worksheets from an application of the Information-Decision-Action (IDA) model.32 These data sources were selected because they contained detailed information about the factors that influenced single human errors in a risk significant incident at a nuclear power plant (NPP).

There are additional databases that gather information about human errors in NPPs (e.g. HFIS33 and H2ERA34), but they gather information about the factors that influence all human performance throughout an entire risk-significant scenario rather than single human errors within the scenario. The information provided by such data sources is too high level to be used to develop a model of PIFs affecting a single human error. Future research efforts should explore methods to incorporate this type of data with the more detailed quantitative information.

sec.title: 3.1 HERA database
sec.p: The HERA database was developed by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and the Idaho National Laboratory. It is designed to collect detailed information about the factors that affect human performance in commercial NPPs. The database contains retrospective analyses of risk-significant NPP operating events that contain at least one human error. The information is gathered from licensee event reports, inspection reports and augmented inspection team reports.

All data encoded in the HERA database are coded on two forms: Worksheet A and Worksheet B.35 A fully coded HERA event contains one Worksheet A and multiple Worksheet B forms. Worksheet A contains a detailed time line of sub-events, i.e. the successes and failures of hardware, human tasks and organizational elements. The term event is used to describe one entire risk-significant incident at a NPP. The entire span of a reportable incident is one event (e.g. one LER would be treated as one event). A sub-event is a single human task, equipment actuation or failure, or external state that occurs during an event. Each event is comprised of dozens to hundreds of sub-events.

Worksheet B is completed for tasks involving human failure or success. Worksheet B contains information about the context of the task and detailed information about what influenced human behavior and how human behavior contributed to the scenario. Human sub-events are classified as either a human success sub-event (HS) or a human failure sub-event (XHE).

Worksheet B is used to gather information on human performance, including an assessment of the relevant PIFs. The 11 PIFs used in the HERA database are presented in Table 2. The HERA PIFs are based on the PIFs suggested in the NRC’s Good Practices for HRA.36 The HERA database expands the PIFs from36 by including specific PIF details, which provide additional information about the state of each PIF. An example of the PIF details for the Communication PIF is provided in Table 3. During HERA coding, the analyst reviews the list of PIF details and selects the details that are relevant to the sub-event. The analyst uses the PIF details to provide additional information about the state of the PIF. There are over 250 PIF details that correspond to positive or negative influences on the human; these are aggregated from multiple HRA sources.

sec.p: The analyst uses the PIF details to provide additional information about the state of the PIF. The state of the PIF generally corresponds to the state of the PIF details: if mostly positive PIF details are checked, the PIF state is ‘adequate’; if mostly negative PIF details are checked, the PIF state is ‘less than adequate’ (LTA). If no PIF details are checked for a PIF, the state of the PIF is ‘nominal/indeterminate’.

sec.title: 3.2 IDA model events
sec.p: The IDA cognitive model37 is used to analyze the behavior of NPP operators during abnormal operating conditions. The IDA model separates PIFs into internal and external factors. However, the focus of the IDA model is on human cognition, so the external PIF list is not comprehensive. An updated version of the IDA model, IDAC (Information, Decision, and Action in crew Context5), expands the IDA PIFs to include a more comprehensive set of external factors and an expanded map of information flow and causal influences.

Four events were analyzed in depth by Mosleh et al.32 using the IDA model. The four IDA events contained nine human error sub-events (similar to HERA XHEs). Each sub-event contains several data sheets that provide classification information and root cause analysis that includes cognitive factors. The data sheets include information gathered from site visits and operator interviews. Contextual information, provided in the IDA event analysis documentation, was used to assign values to external PIFs that were not included in the IDA model.

sec.title: 3.3 Data aggregation
sec.p: Combining data from multiple sources into a single quantitative analysis requires a common framework for interpreting and analyzing the information. The framework for merging data from the HERA and the IDAC events is the structured set of PIFs introduced by Groth.18 This PIF set was developed to produce a consistent set of definitions for use in future HRA methods and to enable the construction of causal models. The set was developed by aggregating information from multiple current HRA methods, three expert workshops, and from event data into a comprehensive set of influencing factors.

Groth’s PIF set provides a common framework that allows data from multiple sources to be combined to inform a causal model. In the PIF set, each PIF is linked to a single aspect of the socio-technical system, similarly to how they are grouped in THERP.1 The top level of the hierarchy contains five categories: machine-based, person-based, team-based, organization-based and situation-based. This division ensures that each PIF is defined with respect to a specific aspect of the socio-technical system, which can help identify the root causes of a human error and supports understanding of causal relationships.

The PIF framework used in the current work is presented in Table 4. This framework includes minor changes to Groth’s original framework, as documented in Groth and Mosleh.38 Using the detailed definitions provided by Groth and Mosleh,38 we carefully mapped the PIFs for each human error event (XHE) in the IDAC and HERA data onto the PIF framework. sec.title: 4 Data analysis techniques
sec.p: To create the base structure of a model it is necessary to determine how the nodes of the model relate to each other. The methodology presented in the section ‘Model development procedure’ uses correlation analysis and factor analysis (FA) to explore patterns in the aggregated data. In the methodology, tetrachoric correlation analysis is used to determine how the PIFs relate to each other. Minimum residuals (Minres) FA is used to identify patterns of PIFs that are linked to human errors. This section provides a brief overview of the data analysis techniques, provides justification for using specific techniques for the data, and explains how they can be interpreted by the HRA community.

sec.title: 4.1 Correlation
sec.p:
Correlation gives a quantitative measure of similarity between two variables – the amount of variance from the common area between them – thus garnering an initial understanding of the variable relationships. Correlation is indicated by a number between
− 1
and 1. A correlation of 1 indicates a perfect increasing linear relationship; a correlation of 0 indicates complete independence between the variables.

For HRA modeling, correlation is used to explore the pairwise relationships between various PIFs. Several different correlation techniques can be used to develop a pairwise correlation matrix. Pearson product moment correlations can be obtained using most commercial software packages, but these correlations are only valid for continuous, normally distributed data. For discrete data, the polychoric correlation technique can be used, if the data is believed represent a latent continuous variable. The fundamental assumption underlying polychoric correlation is that discrete data are representative of an underlying normally distributed model and that somewhere in the model there are thresholds where the variable changes states. For binary data, tetrachoric correlation, a specific case of polychoric correlation, should be used.39,40 In tetrachoric correlation the location of the threshold is estimated by applying a probit function to the data. The probit function is the inverse cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution; it calculates the location of the threshold based on the amount of the curve to the left of the data.41 Polychoric and tetrachoric correlations can be calculated by using the %POLYCHOR macro for SAS42 or the polychor option in the polycor package in R.43

The HRA data used in this research is binary, but the PIFs are believed to represent continuous concepts, so the data satisfy the continuity assumption underlying tetrachoric correlation. It is not known if all of the PIFs are normally distributed, but it has been suggested that underlying distribution is not necessarily restricted to a normal distribution due to the similarity between tetrachoric correlation and item response theory.44–47 Since most human behavior is not truly discrete, tetrachoric correlation is suitable for identifying correlations in the available PIF data.

sec.title: 4.2 Factor analysis
sec.p: For HRA modeling, FA can be used to discover relationships among multiple PIFs and error. FA is a family of multivariate techniques that has been widely used in a number of fields to identify relationships and latent influences in data. Exploratory FA techniques are used to identify different patterns of variance (deviation from the mean) and to define these patterns mathematically; they are often used to develop hypothesis about the data. According to Cattell,48 FA is especially valuable in the behavioral sciences, because behavioral phenomena are often multiply determined, and the independent variables are not easily conceptualized, identified and/or agreed upon.

sec.title: 4.2.1 Overview
sec.p:
Exploratory FA views variance in the observed data as the result of a linear combination of the observed variables and some invisible common factor(s). Starting with an
n
×
n
correlation matrix, FA identifies the magnitude of the common influences, and identifies a new set of
n
factors that contain the same amount of variance as the original data. The first factor accounts for the most variance, the second factor accounts for the second-most variance (i.e. of the remaining variance after subtracting the first factor) and so on. The factor loading matrix contains the correlation between each of the original variables and each new factor.

It is up to the analyst to decide which factors represent meaningful patterns. Important factors will have high eigenvalues (thus explaining relatively large amounts of variance). An eigenvalue greater than 1.0 means that the factor accounts for more than its proportionate share of the original variance. The Kaiser–Guttman rule suggests that analysts should retain all of the factors with eigenvalues greater than 1.0, because the variance encapsulated by each retained factor is greater than the variance explained by the original observable variables. Analysts must also determine which of the original variables are most relevant and which variables have a minimal contribution to each factor. Analysts typically set their own minima based on data, but a commonly suggested rule is that only variables with loadings above
| 0 . 40 |
should be included as part of a factor. There are numerous combinations of FA techniques and FA stopping rules, and there is no single correct technique for any application. The reader is referred to Meyers et al.,49 Hair50 and Velicer and Jackson51 for detailed information about the many different FA methods and factor selection criteria.

sec.title: 4.2.2 Application to HRA data
sec.p: In this research, we posit that certain combinations of PIFs are more likely to produce human errors. The human error data resulted from the influence of the individual PIFs plus some latent influences that magnify the impact of certain combinations of PIFs. The variance in the data can be interpreted as the difference between the observed impact of a PIF on human performance and the expected impact of the PIF if it were acting alone. Factor analysis is used to identify patterns of PIFs that explain more variance than the individual PIFs are expected to produce (that is, the whole is greater than the sum of its parts). We call these patterns error contexts; they are discussed further in the section ‘Error context identification’.

In this research, we used several FA techniques to explore the data. The model presented in this paper is based on an unrotated Minres analysis. The Minres technique52 is an unweighed least-squares method that seeks to minimize the sums of squares of the residual matrix. It is used to maximize the amount of variance explained by the new factors. The analysis was iterative, which allowed us to determine the communality (the maximum level of common influences in the data) and thus characterized the minimum individual influence of each individual PIF.

sec.title: 5 Model development procedure
sec.p: This section presents the procedure for creating a causal model of PIF interactions using the data sources discussed in the section ‘Data sources’ and the quantitative techniques discussed in the section ‘Data analysis techniques’. The procedure presented in this section can be applied to create different causal models with varying degrees of specificity depending on the PIFs selected. Applying the entire methodology will result in a causal model similar to the one displayed in Figure 2.

caption.p: The basic elements of a causal model including directed arcs between performance influencing factors, metrics, and error context nodes.

sec.title: 5.1 PIF and behavior/metric selection
sec.p: The PIF hierarchy documented in Groth and Mosleh38 and reproduced in Table 4 was designed specifically to be used in causal modeling. The hierarchical structure allows various types of information to be aggregated in a traceable manner. Careful selection of the PIFs is an important step in model construction. Which PIFs can be included in a data-driven model depends on the quality and quantity of available data and expert information. Data-based PIF models will use a more collapsed version of the hierarchy PIFs, while models created with more information can include a greater number of PIFs and a large number of metrics for each PIF. The choice of which PIFs and associated metrics to include in the model can be made based on expert judgment or it can be made through a systematic, iterative process wherein quantitative analysis is performed and the PIF set is refined, based on the quantitative results, until a suitable set is selected.

It is suggested to start the analysis with the hierarchy fully expanded and then to refine the set one PIF at a time. To refine the PIF set, the analyst could merge similar PIFs (e.g. Procedures and Tools become Resources), divide a PIF into more categories (e.g. Procedures becomes Procedure availability and Procedure quality) or completely eliminate the PIF from the analysis.

For selection of PIFs using quantitative data, begin with correlation analysis on the fully expanded PIF hierarchy. (PIFs that are present in fewer than 10% or more than 90% of the sub-events are likely to produce erroneous results. It may be beneficial to eliminate these PIFs before running the quantitative analysis to reduce the computational burden.) The analyst should examine the correlation results to identify correlations that are erroneous (e.g. correlations exceeding
| 0 . 95 |
tend to be erroneous in the HERA data). (What is seen as erroneous will vary based on the data set and the analyst. The intention of this step is to allow analysts to remove known outliers without devoting computational resources.) Remove one PIF and repeat the correlation analysis until there are no remaining erroneous correlations.

Once outliers are identified and removed via correlation analysis, the analyst should run a series of FAs on the remaining variables, to further refine the PIF set. It is left to the analysts to determine which FA model and technique is most suitable for their data and which software package to use. While factor loadings should never exceed
1 . 0
, analysis should be allowed to continue if these Heywood cases occur, because they are an indicator of limitations in the data set or model.53 Heywood cases can be eliminated by adding data, by trying a different factor model, or by eliminating outliers.

To refine the PIF set, the analyst should examine the FA results and identify the PIF with the largest Heywood case. The PIF with the largest factor loading should be revised by merging it with another PIF, dividing it into more PIFs, or eliminating it from the quantitative part of the analysis. Repeat the FA, removing one PIF at a time, until factor results are free of Heywood cases. Once all Heywood cases are removed, the analyst may wish to perform significance tests to determine if the factor model is suitable for the final PIF set. If the most significant factor model differs from the factor model used to refine the data set (i.e. if there is a different number of factors), it is advisable to repeat the entire process with the new factor model; this ensures that the final PIF set is based on a significant factor model.

sec.title: 5.2 Error context identification
sec.p: FA is used to identify patterns in the available human performance data. To explain the factor results, we introduce the concept of error contexts.

Since we are analyzing only human failure events from HERA and IDA, the observed patterns can be viewed as visible manifestations of the context underlying the error. This interpretation is justified for factors with eigenvalues greater than
1 . 0
, since an eigenvalue greater than 1.0 indicates that the factor accounts for more than its proportional share of variance.49 Each factor is a group of PIFs that contributes more to human performance errors than would each PIF if acting alone; the whole (factor) is greater than the sum of its parts (PIFs).

In this research, we use FA to identify factors that explain more variance in the data than the individual PIFs are expected to produce. We believe that these factors represent combinations of PIFs that have a synergistic effect on error. We call these patterns error contexts (ECs), which are groups of PIFs that are more likely to produce human errors when they occur together.

sec.title: 5.3 Model structuring
sec.p: Once the set of PIFs has been finalized, each PIF becomes a node in the model. To build a data-informed model, run correlation analysis and FA on the final PIF set and add a model node for each factor with an eigenvalue greater than 1.0. It is advisable to use different colors or shapes to differentiate between EC nodes and PIF nodes to reduce the likelihood of model misinterpretation.

The directed arcs in the model should be based on causal relationships.25 It is up to the analyst to determine the nature of the relationships between different variables. Causal information can be learned from patterns in the data or it may come from literature, current models or direct expert elicitation.

Causal relationships cannot be directly learned from the observational data available in HRA, but correlation and FA can be used to assist the analyst in identifying causal relationships. Since the PIFs are orthogonally defined (see Groth and Mosleh38 for a definition of orthogonality as it applies to the PIFs), there is no overlap between the PIF definitions. Therefore, all observed variance must be due to some kind of causal among the PIFs. Figure 3 discusses three types of causal relationships anticipated in HRA data.

caption.p: Types of causal relationships that may contribute to observed patterns in the human reliability analysis data. Left: performance influencing factors (PIFs) A and B are independent of each other, but they both directly influence the error context X. Center: PIF A causes (or is a condition for) PIF B. B directly influences the error context X, and A indirectly influences X through B. Right: PIF A and PIF B are both influenced by a common parent, PIF C. A and B may or may not influence the same error context X.

sec.p:
To build a model based on the current HRA data, use the results of the correlation analysis and FA to help determine where directed arcs should be placed. For the ECs identified via FA, draw an arc from each PIF that loads on that factor (in the current model, PIFs with factor loadings greater than 0.3 indicate that the PIF loads on the factor). Next, identify pairs of PIFs with correlations that exceed a specific threshold (for analysis of the current data,
0 . 3
; this correlation cut-off value; this may be adjusted for different data sets), and determine if a direct relationship exists between the PIFs. Draw arcs between nodes where direct logical relationships exist. If no clear logical relationship between the two PIFs exists, the nodes may have a common parent node, or they may be part of the same EC. ECs can subsume some of the correlation-based arcs. The analyst should examine the arcs between PIFs that are also linked to the same EC. Arcs between PIFs may be removed if they are part of the same EC and the analyst determines that they have a weak causal relationship. It may be helpful to refer to human factors literature to determine the direction of the arcs and to validate these relationships.

If desired, augment the data-driven model with additional expert information. For models that contain both data-driven and expert-informed nodes and arcs, it is advisable to differentiate between the arcs rooted in the data and the arcs rooted in expert judgment. Dotted arcs should be drawn where expert opinion is used to identify relationships.

sec.title: 5.4 Model quantification
sec.p: Model quantification entails populating a full probability table for each node. Given a well-populated database, conditional probability tables for the BN can be developed automatically. In fact, both the network structure and the conditional probabilities can be automatically ‘learned’ given sufficient data.26,54 Automatic quantification requires a large sample size and often imposes distributional assumptions on the data. Each variable relationship must be represented properly in the data sample; there cannot be missing data due to unobservable or infrequent variables.28 Variables could be under-represented in the data due to difficulty measuring them or limited opportunities to collect data on specific subsets; any missing values must be filled in by experts before automatic quantification can be realized.55,56

Assessment of conditional probability becomes more complicated when one must rely on a small sample with no information about some of the variables. One advantage of using BNs is that different sources of data could be used to assess the probabilities for different nodes, although this must be done carefully.28 There are few methodologies that specifically address how to quantify a BN based on FA results. Two promising methods that can be used with HRA-style data are provided by Almond57 and Bonafede and Giudici.58

While some BN experts suggest that quantification should be postponed until the graphical structure of the model is considered robust, for HRA is it advisable to treat model quantification as part of an iterative approach to HRA model development and data collection. This iterative process can be used to improve HRA models incrementally to reflect the best available data and knowledge. Working through the full model-development process, including quantification, can help expose limitations and weaknesses in available data sources. Identifying these limitations can help the industry refine the collection of HRA data so that it can better inform the HRA models. The model presented in the next section is intended to provide a starting point for exploring HRA data.

sec.title: 5.5 Summary of model building procedure
sec.p: This section summarizes the procedure for creating a quantified causal model of PIFs using HRA data. The procedure can be implemented to create an entirely data-based model, or the data-based model can be augmented with expert information to produce a more comprehensive model.

The data must satisfy the fundamental criteria as outlined by Groth and Mosleh.38 Suggested threshold values are based on the currently available data and may be adjusted as additional data becomes available. The methodology assumes that data have been mapped onto the PIF hierarchy and that the PIFs have two states (Adequate versus LTA). Given additional levels of discretization, the methodology will start by identifying and merging similar PIF states (e.g. totally inadequate, partially inadequate) for each PIF and then proceed to identifying and merging similar PIFs.

sec.title: 6 PIF model development and insights
sec.p: This section presents a sample HRA model that was developed by applying the proposed methodology from the section ‘Model development procedure’ to the two sources of data discussed in the section ‘Data sources’. The model presented in this section is a demonstration of how the methodology can be used to build a quantitative model. More importantly, the model shows that it is possible to garner insight from data exploration, even with limited data, and that data can be used to build predictive models for HRA.

This model is a starting point for the next generation of data-informed HRA methods. The methodology provides a path forward for carefully incorporating emerging sources of human performance data into HRA methodologies. This type of model is intended to change the way that HRA calculates human error probabilities, but the use of limited data alone is not sufficient to produce a model that can replace current HRA methodologies. In future papers, we will discuss efforts to expand the model using additional sources of data.

sec.title: 6.1 Model nodes
sec.p: The scope of the current model was guided by the level of resolution that the current data supports. Ideally, each of the PIFs from the hierarchy would be represented as a single node in the model. However, a purely data-driven model will not capture all of the important variables that influence human performance without additional data. The set of nodes used in the model was developed by using the procedure for collapsing the PIF hierarchy, discussed in the section ‘Model development procedure’. In order to retain information from the data, PIFs were merged together whenever possible. Behaviors/metrics for the PIFs are not included in this model due to data limitations.

The set of model nodes is presented in Table 6. The final set of nodes in the model contains the nine elements that had sufficient data to be included in the model and that provided convergent factor groupings with correlations below
| 1 . 0 |
. Each model node generalizes a number of concepts that cover different dimensions of human performance in a NPP. The labels used in the model are generalizations of a number of PIFs, which are defined in more detail by Groth and Mosleh.38 The remainder of this section provides justification for merging PIFs from the entire hierarchy (Figure 4) to create the nine model nodes.

sec.p: Training had sufficient data to be retained as a model node; no other PIFs were merged with it. The Team model node represents all of the team-related PIFs from the hierarchy. It is comprised of Direct supervision, Role awareness, Communication, Team coordination, and Team cohesion.

Staffing, Scheduling, and Compliance were collapsed into Management activities. The Management activities PIF was then merged with Safety culture and Corrective action program to form one model node for organizational attitude/culture. Both Management activities and the Corrective action program demonstrate how the highest members of the organization set priorities. Safety culture becomes visible in additional ways throughout the plant, but the safety message comes from the top. Together, these PIFs illustrate the organizational attitude toward safety.

Procedures, Tools, and Necessary information were combined into the Resources model node. Most resources are provided by the organization, although necessary information can be provided by other team members (e.g. logbooks). Different types of resources tend to be more relevant for different plant tasks (e.g. tools are typically used in maintenance tasks, whereas in many control room situations the procedures are the ‘tool’ required), but for human performance modeling, all of the resource serve a similar purpose.

Morale/motivation/attitude, Bias, and Attention were combined into the Attitude node in the model. Biased behavior or intentional inattention can be an indicator of a worker’s underlying attitude. Bias can also result in improperly assigning attention. In retrospective analysis it is often difficult to differentiate between lack of attention and intentional disregard of certain information. The personal behaviors Compliance, Prioritization, Information use, and Task order are used as metrics of Attitude.

Skills, knowledge and experience, and Physical and psychological abilities were combined into the Knowledge node, because all three PIFs refer to the internal resources available to each individual. Familiarity with situation was also included in this node because familiarity is partially the result of increased experience.

The Conditioning events PIF was merged with Task complexity to provide the Complexity node, which describes the inherent situational difficulty. Both degraded machine conditions and complex tasks increase the externally observable demands of a scenario.

The Loads/perceptions node captures the level of cognitive demand that the worker feels. Task loads, Time load and Other loads capture how the scenario demands (including those captured in the Complexity node) are internalized as cognitive demands (loads). Perception of urgency, Perception of severity, and Perception of decision impact PIFs, which are aggregated as Perception of situation, are observable manifestations of internal stress. The Perception of situation PIFs serve as indicators that the person is experiencing an increased cognitive demand.

HSI was combined with System responses to form the Machine node. Both PIFs relate to how the human perceives and interacts with the machine; HSI refers to the physical system design whereas System responses refers to the person’s mental model of the system. These PIFs were somewhat under-represented in the data, in part due to the difficulty of assessing them in retrospective analysis. However, they are conceptually important enough that they were retained in the final model.
Environment could not be included in the analysis individually and did not sufficiently correlate with other PIFs to be combined with any other PIFs.

sec.title: 6.2.1 Quantitative analysis results
sec.p: After selecting the set of model nodes, we ran correlation analysis and FA to explore relationships between the nodes. The correlation table is presented in Table 7. The full set of raw data used to create this model are provided by Groth.18

caption.p: Tetrachoric correlation values used to develop the structure of the human reliability analysis model.

sec.p: We ran several exploratory FAs to explore patterns in the data. We ran principal FA (PFA) and Minres factor models for between one and five factors, and we explored unrotated model as well as varimax and promax rotation options. The analysis results shown in Table 7 are the output of an unrotated, Minres FA. This is the factor model we used to build the BN model.

We selected the four-factor model based on the eigenvalues of the resulting factors and the shape of the scree plot. The scree plot showed discontinuity after the fourth factor. For the PFA, the first four factors had eigenvalues greater than 1.0. The fourth factor in the Minres results has an eigenvalue of 0.98, but we elected to retain this factor based on the scree plot and the PFA eigenvalues. In both PFA and Minres FA, the four-factor model had the highest
p
-value of the five models tested.

The FA on the available human error data resulted in four ECs. The first EC is created by the combination of LTA Training, Team and Complexity. EC1 captures the notion that some human errors occur when teamwork and training are insufficient to respond to a complex, dynamic scenario. The second EC is adequate Knowledge, LTA Attitude, and LTA Organizational culture. Thus, EC2 suggests that poor compliance behavior at a personal or organizational level can lead to errors, regardless of the complexity of the situation. The third EC is a combination of LTA Attitude, Loads, and Complexity; it is most applicable in situations where Organizational culture is adequate. EC3 suggests that, even in good organizational cultures, complex situations can cause high cognitive loads, which lead to poor work attitudes and result in human errors. EC4 is LTA Resources and Complexity. This EC suggests that having inadequate resources can lead to errors in complex situations (or that complex situations often exceed the scope of the available resources).

The ordering of the ECs is important. The first EC captures the greatest amount of variance in the data, as show by the eigenvalue in Table 8. The second EC captures the greatest amount of remaining variance, after removing the first EC, and so on. This suggests that the PIFs that form EC1 may be more important than the PIFs that affect EC4. Complexity is present in many of the ECs, which suggests that situational complexity is an overarching factor that leads to human errors in power plants.

caption.p: Factor analysis results for the nine nodes in the human reliability analysis model.

sec.title: 6.2.2 Data-driven insights into PIF relationships
sec.p: Many of the correlations seen in Table 7 support relationships that reflect expert intuition. This section offers some insight into what type of intuition supports the relationships that are apparent in the data. Some of the relationships suggested by the correlation results cannot be explained by a causal relationship between PIFs. For example, Complexity shows a high correlation with Team. These PIF relationships are subsumed by the ECs discussed in the next section. It is suggested that human performance literature should be used to validate the suggested relationships among the PIFs before producing an operational HRA model.

There are numerous causal arcs into Loads/perceptions. There are high correlations between Loads/perceptions and Training, Team, Machine, Complexity, and Attitude. Each of these correlations has been interpreted as a causal contributor to Loads/perceptions because they all directly affect the way personnel perceive the situation. This is because perceptions and loads are the worker’s personal assessment of the situation. Intrinsic worker attitude also causally contributes to the individual’s loads and perceptions because the characteristics that manifest as attitude also affect individual perception.

The causal arrow from Knowledge to Attitude represents a negative correlation. The arrow implies that adequate knowledge contributes to LTA personal attitudes, or that LTA knowledge contributes to adequate attitudes among personnel. This can be seen in situations where experienced personnel use work-arounds (non-compliant attitude) to deal with a situation. Less experienced personnel may not know as much about the system and therefore may not be able to develop work-arounds for the system. They must rely on available resources and tend to approach a situation more cautiously to compensate for their reduced knowledge. This effect is observed in a HERA event (HERA event code EGG-HFRU-10085) where an experienced worker made an error because he relied on his memory of the reporting requirements instead of consulting the appropriate procedures. A less experienced worker may have avoided making this error, because LTA knowledge about the situation would force the worker to consult the procedure.

The causal arrow from Resources to Complexity is logical, because lack of resources results in additional complexity. This can be seen in situations where there are inadequate procedures. Inadequate procedures may contribute to complexity in several ways. When there are no procedures for a situation, the required actions are knowledge based. Knowledge-based actions are more complex than rule-based actions. Extremely complex situations are also more likely than routine situations to be outside the scope of procedures. However, we cannot draw a causal arrow from resources to complexity based on this logic, because the complexity of the situation doesn’t necessarily cause the lack of resources.

The causal arcs from Organizational culture to Machine and from Organizational culture to Complexity represent a negative correlation. The negative correlation here could be an artifact of the sources of data: organizations with good Organizational culture tend to be more willing to report problems with the machine or may more accurately report the complexity of a situation. So the causal arrow in the model does not necessarily imply that adequate Organizational culture causes inadequate machinery or complexity, rather that adequate Organizational culture causes increased reporting of inadequate machinery and complex situations. Additionally, organizations with inadequate machinery must be more attentive to the machinery and thus benefit from a positive organizational culture. As additional data becomes available, further analysis should be done to determine the nature of the relationships indicated by these links, or if this link is the result of under-representation of machine factors in the data.

sec.title: 6.2.3 Error Context insights
sec.p: In this paper, we have introduced the term error context to describe certain combinations of PIFs that are more likely to produce human errors than the individual PIFs acting alone. The ECs that emerged from the quantitative analysis suggest that human errors in NPPs can result from four types of situations.

Error Context 1 suggests that errors occur when teamwork and training are insufficient to respond to a complex, dynamic scenario. The relationships among the EC1 PIFs suggest several things about how errors could be prevented in NPPs. During situations with high Complexity, including those that contain degraded machine states (Conditioning Events), Teamwork and Training become exceptionally important. A well-functioning team can reduce the perceived loads and the situation complexity by efficiently organizing and dividing tasks. Training can contribute to the proper functioning of the team and also contributes to personnel knowledge, which affects how a person perceives the load and the complexity of the situation.

Error Context 2 suggests that poor compliance behavior at a personal or organizational level can lead to errors, regardless of the complexity of the situation. The second error context is Organizational culture, Attitude, and Knowledge. The LTA states of Organizational culture and Attitude are positively correlated with the EC, and LTA Knowledge is negatively correlated with it. This suggests that LTA Knowledge is not a contributor to this ‘type’ of error. Rather there is not inadequate knowledge; we can’t say that the people are particularly knowledgeable, but they do not lack necessary knowledge. The combination of adequate Knowledge with LTA Attitude suggests that the attitude of the worker plays a major role in errors committed by experienced personnel. The data support the theory that workers with less knowledge or experience tend to compensate for their inexperience by working more carefully. Experienced personnel are prone to making mistakes due to carelessness or poor work practices, including compliance and prioritization behaviors. Poor work practices are rarely limited to one member of an organization; rather, LTA Organizational culture creates an environment that allows worker attitudes to decline.

Error Context 3 captures the notion that, even in good organizational cultures, complex situations can cause high cognitive loads, which lead to poor work attitudes and result in human errors. The third error context is Organizational culture, Attitude, Loads/perceptions, and Complexity. The fact that both Loads and Complexity load on this factor is logical – a more complex situation will increase perceived loads. Likewise, the number of simultaneous tasks (actual loads) can also increase complexity. Attitude plays a role in how situations, especially complex situations, are translated into perceived loads. Organizational culture has a negative correlation with this PIF, which suggests that this factor is linked to adequate organizational culture. This is likely because the second error context (which has a higher eigenvalue and thus explains more of the variance) absorbs most of the situations where Organizational culture is LTA.

Error Context 4 suggests that having inadequate resources can lead to errors in complex situations (or that complex situations often exceed the scope of the available resources). The fourth error context is Resources and Complexity. This is the factor that explains the least variance, which suggests that inadequate resources are not seen alone in many errors. Again this EC is linked to Complexity, which is logical because complex situations may be unfamiliar to personnel and thus personnel rely on the resources, especially procedures, more heavily.

HSI does not load on any of the factors and therefore does not appear in an error context. This is logical because of the generally unchanging nature of HSI; workers accept the system as it is designed. Operators tend to compensate for system shortcomings (e.g. they develop work-arounds to deal with bad display). Maintenance workers also develop work-arounds (e.g. a worker who must enter a narrow space between display panels might turn sideways to avoid bumping into a panel).

The quantitative analyses support many relationships already theorized to exist. It is interesting to note that Complexity loads on the first, third, and fourth factors, which suggests that complexity is an especially important contributor to human error. This makes intuitive sense, since humans typically do not have the opportunity to commit an error if they are not interacting with the plant. Complex situations may include failures of multiple system components, failure masking (e.g. failed sensors that obscure hardware failures), and unanticipated plant conditions. These complex situations may be outside the scope of worker training and available procedures, so worker behavior shifts from rule-based to knowledge-based, which increases the likelihood of error.

sec.title: 8 Conclusions
sec.p: Within the HRA community, there is a widely acknowledged need for an improved HRA method with a more robust scientific basis. This paper presents three significant advances in the direction of developing a more robust scientific basis for HRA. These advances are stepping stones toward the next generation of HRA methods.

First, this paper demonstrates that it is possible to garner insight into human performance from small sets of data, and that HRA data can be used to validate expert intuition about the factors that drive human performance and to validate relationships among these factors. Few current HRA methods use quantitative data as a basis for predicting HEPs, much less as a basis for characterizing the relationships documented in the model.

There have been several international efforts to collect human performance data to validate HRA models, but these efforts have focused largely on validating or improving the quantitative aspects of existing HRA models. The current HRA data collection efforts offer the opportunity to build an HRA method that produces accurate, traceable quantitative results. However, this data can also support the development of causal insights that can strengthen the qualitative basis of HRA models.

Human performance data can be used to explore causal relationships among PIFs and errors in real-world situations. These inter-relationships can be encoded in a causal HRA model that provides both qualitative and quantitative insight. This type of model enables HRA analysts to predict the probability of human error events from a robust technical basis, and further enables the industry to explain why human errors happen and what can be done to prevent them.

Furthermore, the paper introduces a methodology and a framework for using data to improve the existing HRA data collection efforts, and path to improve the way that HRA data are used to build models. The use of a data-informed, expert-verified HRA model adds a new level of validity to an industry where there are no benchmarks to validate existing models. However, models are only as good as the data that go into creating them. Inadequate data collection limits the effectiveness of models, and inadequate modeling impacts how data are collected; this problem is of primary importance in HRA.59 Without attempts to build data-informed models, there is no framework to expose weaknesses in the current data or to influence how data are collected.

The causal model presented in this paper explores two sources of data to see what types of insights can be gathered and what types of weaknesses limit the use of current data sources to produce quantitative insights. There are many limitations in the data and in the analysis that bring up questions about the validity of the causal model. The available data do not meet ideal conditions for statistical analysis due to the limited quantity of data and the form of the data. All of the available data sources treat the PIFs as binary variables, which limits the applicability of many commonly used statistical techniques that assume multivariate normality in the data. There are large data gaps, especially in HSI, Environment and Physical and psychological abilities; these PIFs are under-represented in the data and it is not clear if this is due to the low frequency of occurrence in real events or due to limitations in the use of retrospective data. Some of the relationships revealed in the quantitative results may be counterintuitive. We are not in a position to challenge the results of the data or the intuition of HRA experts. Rather, we are presenting a model built from data, which provides a path forward for refining the data collection efforts and for exploring the validity of the expert intuition that forms the basis of current HRA methods. Future work is needed to ensure that the data used to produce the causal model are of sufficient quantity and quality for predictive modeling.

A BN model of PIFs can be used to estimate HEPs, but the proof-of-concept BN presented in this paper is not intended replace current HRA quantitative methods. The data-driven model presented in this paper is intended to demonstrate the proposed methodology and illustrate the type of insights that can be obtained through the process. It should be seen as a starting point for future model development and validation rather than a definitive model for HRA.

Thirdly, the use of BNs and the proposed PIF hierarchy provides a framework for incorporating multiple sources information into a single model that addresses many of the shortcomings of current methods. This paper presents a roadmap for maximizing the use of quantitative information to improve the technical basis of HRA.

Of the international efforts to collect human performance data for HRA, none of the efforts has gathered enough data to build a predictive HRA model. It is clear that there is significant value in collecting HRA data, but none of these efforts alone can produce a model that addresses all of the limitations currently plaguing HRA. The methodology presented in this paper provides a framework for synthesizing information garnered from multiple data collection efforts, from existing HRA methods, from expert intuition, and from cognitive psychology into a next-generation HRA method. The proposed framework enables HRA researchers to use both empirical data and theoretical models to produce HEP estimates.

This paper has presented a methodology to use available data to produce a BN causal model of PIF relationships for HRA and a proof-of-concept model based on two sources of data. The methodology provides a direct path for using quantitative data as a basis for the next generation of HRA models. Using both theoretical models and empirical data in the same model provides a level of validity greater than any current HRA model.

The model presented in this paper demonstrates that quantitative data from multiple sources can be used to provide qualitative insights into human performance, and that quantitative data can be used as the basis for building a predictive HRA model. This model is intended as a starting point for using quantitative information to enhance HRA. It is part of a larger framework18 which enables expert intuition, theory and available data to be incorporated in a rigorous manner to produce a robust HRA model.

Exploring real-world data offers the opportunity to justify expert intuition that is well documented in literature and in laboratory experiments. It also offers the opportunity to challenge expert intuition and laboratory experiments that may not be reflected in real-world situations. The use of BN models can advance the practice of HRA from equation-based quantification of human error probabilities to quantification based on understanding of the underlying causal relationships that drive human performance.
